title: 107_hr2313
content: The Act titled "Crane Tithe Tax Act of 2001" repeals the taxation of corporations. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 repeals various tax provisions related to corporate income, alternative minimum tax for corporations, unrelated business income tax, accumulated earnings tax, personal holding company tax, alternative tax for certain mutual savings banks, and tax imposed on life insurance companies. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 repeals tax provisions on various entities including life insurance companies, mutual insurance companies, other insurance companies, regulated investment companies, real estate investment trusts, and income of foreign corporations connected with United States business. SEC. 3 introduces a 10 percent income tax rate for individuals under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. A 10 percent income tax is imposed on individuals based on earned income exceeding the exemption amount, which is $10,000 adjusted for inflation. The tax law imposes a 10 percent income tax on individuals with earned income exceeding the exemption amount of $10,000 adjusted for inflation. The cost-of-living adjustment is based on the Consumer Price Index for all-urban consumers published by the Department of Labor. The tax law imposes a 10 percent income tax on individuals with earned income exceeding the exemption amount of $10,000 adjusted for inflation. Earned income includes wages, salaries, and other employee compensation, subject to rounding rules for increases not multiples of $10. The tax law defines earned income as net earnings from self-employment and dividends from personal service corporations or for services, excluding pensions, annuities, and tips. The tax law defines earned income as net earnings from self-employment and dividends from personal service corporations or for services, excluding pensions, annuities, and tips. Fringe benefits included as earned income should be valued at the employer's cost. SEC. 4. Amnesty for all prior tax liability states that no person will be liable for any tax imposed by the Internal Revenue Code for taxable years before January 1, 2000, with exceptions for amounts paid before the enactment of the Act and taxes related to illegal activities. SEC. 5 repeals specific deductions, credits, and exclusions from individual income. SEC. 6 repeals estate and gift taxes. SEC. 7 specifies effective dates. The amendments made by this Act apply to taxable years after enactment. Repeal of estate and gift taxes applies to estates of decedents dying after enactment. The Secretary of the Treasury must submit technical changes to the Committee on Ways and Means within 90 days of enactment. The Secretary of the Treasury must submit technical changes to the Committee on Ways and Means within 90 days of enactment to reflect changes in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 made by this Act.
